title: 111_s788
content: The "m-SPAM Act of 2009" is cited as the short title. Certain qualifying messages are exempted from the definition of mobile service commercial message. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 is amended to define "mobile service commercial message" as a commercial electronic mail message sent to a wireless device without prior consent. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 is amended to define a "mobile service commercial message" as a commercial electronic mail message sent to a wireless device without prior consent. This excludes messages that facilitate, confirm, or provide information related to a commercial transaction, warranty, product recall, safety, security, or ongoing commercial relationships. The sender can send messages regarding changes in subscription terms, account status, or periodic account statements for ongoing commercial relationships. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "short message" and a "wireless device" in relation to the regulations on sending messages related to employment relationships or benefits, delivering goods or services, and transactions previously agreed upon. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 regarding the sending of short messages and mobile service commercial messages by providers to subscribers at no charge unless the subscriber opts out. The curr_chunk amends the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 by requiring providers of commercial mobile service to follow specific guidelines for sending messages to subscribers. The curr_chunk prohibits unauthorized mobile service commercial messages containing unsolicited advertisements. The curr_chunk amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages to individuals without their prior authorization. It also provides definitions for terms like "commercial mobile service" and "mobile service commercial message." The curr_chunk adds provisions to the Communications Act of 1934 regarding the sending of mobile service commercial messages. It specifies exceptions for sending messages between wireless devices or from a provider to its subscribers at no cost. Additionally, it clarifies that state laws are not affected by these amendments. The curr_chunk clarifies that state laws regarding mobile service commercial messages are not affected by the amendments made by this Act. Mobile service commercial messages containing unsolicited advertisements sent to cellular telephones are explicitly prohibited. The Federal Trade Commission will revise the do-not-call registry provisions to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages to numbers on the registry, except for messages sent by the service provider to its subscribers at no cost. The Federal Trade Commission will revise the do-not-call registry provisions to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages to numbers on the registry, except for messages sent by the service provider to its subscribers at no cost, as defined in section 332(d) of the Communications Act of 1934.
